CAFe: Cost and Age aware Federated Learning

Sahan Liyanaarachchi University of MarylandCollege ParkUSA sahanl@umd.edu ,  Kanchana Thilakarathna University of SydneySydneyAustralia kanchana.thilakarathna@sydney.edu.au  and  Sennur Ulukus University of MarylandCollege ParkUSA ulukus@umd.edu
Abstract.

In many federated learning (FL) models, a common strategy employed to ensure the progress in the training process, is to wait for at least M𝑀M clients out of the total N𝑁N clients to send back their local gradients based on a reporting deadline T𝑇T, once the parameter server (PS) has broadcasted the global model. If enough clients do not report back within the deadline, the particular round is considered to be a failed round and the training round is restarted from scratch. If enough clients have responded back, the round is deemed successful and the local gradients of all the clients that responded back are used to update the global model. In either case, the clients that failed to report back an update within the deadline would have wasted their computational resources. Having a tighter deadline (small T𝑇T) and waiting for a larger number of participating clients (large M𝑀M) leads to a large number of failed rounds and therefore greater communication cost and computation resource wastage. However, having a larger T𝑇T leads to longer round durations whereas smaller M𝑀M may lead to noisy gradients. Therefore, there is a need to optimize the parameters M𝑀M and T𝑇T such that communication cost and the resource wastage is minimized while having an acceptable convergence rate. In this regard, we show that the average age of a client at the PS appears explicitly in the theoretical convergence bound, and therefore, can be used as a metric to quantify the convergence of the global model. We provide an analytical scheme to select the parameters M𝑀M and T𝑇T in this setting.

Federated learning, age of information, resource efficiency.
††copyright: none††doi: ††conference: ; ;

1. Introduction

Federated learning (FL) was first introduced in (McMahan et al., 2017) as a new machine learning paradigm where the task of model training is carried out in a decentralized structure so as to maintain data privacy among the participating entities. Since its emergence, it has been extensively used in a variety of real world applications such as banking applications, healthcare applications, human mobility predication and recommendation systems where data privacy is critical (Feng et al., 2020; Li et al., 2020a). As such, FL is also increasingly becoming popular in mobile/IoT networks and mobile edge computing as a private and secure method of leveraging data produced by mobile/IoT devices.

A typical FL model consists of a parameter sever (PS) along with several clients each with a local dataset and their collective goal is to train the global model at the PS without explicitly revealing their local data to the PS. This is achieved through multiple communication/training rounds between the PS and the clients where at the beginning of each round, the PS broadcasts its model weights to the clients and then each client computes a local gradient based on the broadcasted global model. These local gradients are then sent back to the PS where they are aggregated and used to update the global model. This process is repeated until the global model at the PS has converged. This technique is often referred to as federated averaging (FedAvg) which was proposed in (McMahan et al., 2017; Konencny et al., 2016) and shown to converge under the assumptions that the client participation is uniform and data is uniformly distributed among all the clients (i.i.d. data distribution across clients).

However, in many practical applications, the client datasets are non i.i.d., computation resources of clients are not uniform and network connectivity is unreliable, leading to non-uniform client participation. To this end, there have been many iterations of FedAvg in recent years. The convergence of the FedAvg algorithm under non i.i.d. data distributions was explicitly studied in (Li et al., 2020b) under the settings of full and partial client participation where the authors show that even under data heterogeneity FedAvg achieves convergence with an appropriately chosen decaying learning rate.

In addition to data heterogeneity among clients, another key challenge that arises in the FL models, is the presence of stragglers among clients. If the FL model waits for all clients before updating the model, then the round duration would be dominated by the stragglers. One way to mitigate the straggler issue is to update the global model in an asynchronous manner (Xie et al., 2019; Xu et al., 2021). However, in this case, the aggregation of delayed gradients must be handled appropriately (Li and Gong, 2023). Another simple but effective technique is to terminate the training rounds based on a reporting deadline (Chen et al., 2021; Zhang et al., 2022).

As a result of many iterations and variants proposed over the years, it has become a significant challenge to configure a FL system to attain optimal performance with minimum resource wastage under a heterogeneous environment. It is common to select a portion of clients as learners for each round, and a reporting deadline to improve the efficiency of the system (Abdelmoniem et al., 2023). System developers often rely on trial and error experimental strategies to determine appropriate values for these hyper-parameters. However, inaccurate hyper-parameters can lead to significant resource wastage and lower model performance (Zhang et al., 2023). For example, if clients are not able to complete a local training round before the reporting deadline due to low computation resources of clients and/or network delays, scarce resources will be wasted at client devices. Especially in mobile/IoT networks, where every bit of resources at devices is paramount, such inefficiencies must be avoided.

In this paper, we deduce fundamental relationships among model performance and resource heterogeneity with the aim of minimizing the resource wastage and communication cost, while maintaining an acceptable level of performance which often is determined by the convergence of model and the time for convergence. In order to quantify the performance of the FL framework, we propose to utilize the average age of clients (AoC) at PS.

The average age of information (AoI) was introduced in (Kaul et al., 2012) as a metric to measure the timeliness of communication systems (A. Kosta and Angelakis, 2017; Sun et al., 2019; Yates et al., 2020). The importance of timeliness in FL was addressed in (Buyukates and Ulukus, 2021) where they consider exponential waiting times between client availability windows. This was later extended by (Mitra and Ulukus, 2023) to an asynchronous hierarchical FL system. In this work, we show that through convergence analysis, for the FL model considered, AoC is in fact a direct quantifier for model performance. In particular, we show that the average AoC of users appears explicitly in the theoretical convergence bound, and therefore, can be used as a metric to quantify the convergence of the global model. That is, we show that lower average AoC leads to faster convergence. Therefore, the aim of our work is to find a good FL scheme that achieves timely communication with the clients and at the same time minimizes the resource wastage and communication costs incurred.

To summarize our contributions:

  • •

    We introduce age of clients (AoC) as a metric to quantify the model performance and show that when the total number clients is comparably larger than the number of learners in each training round, the average AoC at PS is directly related to the model performance in terms of the deviation from the optimal point (optimality gap) and time for convergence. In particular, we prove through theoretical convergence analysis and numerical validation, that lower AoC leads to better model performance.

  • •

    We propose metrics to quantify resource wastage and communication costs and provide analytical expressions to compute them for a given FL model. These cost metrics along with the age metric are used to find optimal hyper-parameters M𝑀M and T𝑇T that are required to attain the desired levels of resource efficiency and model performance.

  • •

    We develop two resource efficient schemes: (i) age weighted update, and (ii) aggregated gradient update; that can be implemented in the presence of heterogeneous clients distributions. Through numerical results, we show that the introduced schemes help mitigate issues arising from biased or adversarial clients. Numerical results show that there is a significant performance gain when using age weighted updates compared to a conventional FedAvg update when the number of clients with biased datasets is high for the considered FL model.

2. Related Work

Recently, there has been growing interest in the domain of cost aware FL. (Xue et al., 2022) considers the problem of jointly analyzing client association, transmission and computation optimization for a hierarchical FL (HFL) system with over the air computing where they decouple the joint problem into a client association subproblem and a resource optimization subproblem and solve them via backward induction. In the REFL framework introduced in (Abdelmoniem et al., 2023), the goal is to jointly optimize resource efficiency along with the time to accuracy. They consider a reporting deadline based FL model with varying client availability periods and propose an intelligent participant selection algorithm to maximize the resource diversity of the FL training process. They also propose a staleness aware aggregation technique to utilize the updates of stragglers.

SAFA (Wu et al., 2020) and FLeet (Damaskinos et al., 2022) are other schemes which implement a reporting deadline and aim to maximize the resource efficiency with the use of stale updates. SAFA collects all the updates it receives regardless of the round deadline and only applies updates that do not exceed a bounded staleness threshold. FLeet implements a staleness based dampening factor to utilize all the received updates. Oort (Lai et al., 2021) is another framework which studies the trade-off between faster training and resource diversity where they employ a participant selection algorithm to select faster learners. This minimizes the round duration at the expense of under-utilizing the datasets of slower clients.

Another problem of interest in this domain is the problem of optimal hyper-parameter selection. FedTune (Zhang et al., 2023) studies this problem and introduces an algorithm to select the optimal system parameters to optimize to computation time, transmission time, computation load and transmission load of the involved FL system.

Age aware FL (Liu et al., 2021) has also been studied in the past, where the focus has been to design scheduling policies using age based metrics. (Yang et al., 2020) introduces a new metric called age of update (AoU), which is similar to AoC in our work, and uses it as a metric to design an age based scheduling policy which can increase the training efficiency. The importance of age in FL has been highlighted in all these prior works. However, age’s direct link to the model performance has not been explored theoretically in them. Our work is the first to explore the fundamental link between the age and convergence in FL, together with cost aspects of FL. In fact, we show that age of a typical client is what controls the convergence rate of FL.

3. System Model

Consider the FL setting shown in Figure 1, where the global model at the PS is trained using N𝑁N clients. At the beginning of each training round t𝑡t, the PS broadcasts its current global model weights wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t} to all the N𝑁N clients. Each client then uses these global model weights to train on their local data to produce localized gradients, which are then transmitted back to the PS for aggregation. We assume that for each client, the total time taken for down-link, up-link and the localized training is encapsulated by an exponential distribution with rate λ𝜆\lambda. Let Xksubscript𝑋𝑘X_{k} represent the time from the beginning of the training round to the time at which the PS received the update from the k𝑘kth client. Then, Xk∼E​x​p​(λ)similar-tosubscript𝑋𝑘𝐸𝑥𝑝𝜆X_{k}\sim Exp(\lambda) and i.i.d. over k𝑘k.

In each training round, we assume the PS waits a time T𝑇T, until at least M𝑀M clients have provided their local gradients before updating the global model. If the number of clients that sent back their local gradients by time T𝑇T is less than M𝑀M, we say that the training round has failed. If a training round fails, the PS will discard all the received updates, re-broadcast the global model weights and restart the training round. If at least M𝑀M clients send back their local gradients by time T𝑇T, then the PS will use the gradients of all the clients that responded back by time T𝑇T to update the global model.

Let the local dataset at client k𝑘k be represented by Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}. The goal of the PS is to minimize a loss function l​(⋅)𝑙⋅l(\cdot) using the data distributed among the N𝑁N clients. This can be expressed as a distributed optimization problem as follows,

(1) minw⁡{F​(w)=1N​∑k=1NFk​(w)},subscript𝑤𝐹𝑤1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤\displaystyle\min_{w}\left\{F(w)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N}F_{k}(w)\right\},

where Fk​(w)=N​|Dk|∑i|Di|​∑d∈Dkl​(w,d)|Dk|subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝑁subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑑subscript𝐷𝑘𝑙𝑤𝑑subscript𝐷𝑘F_{k}(w)=\frac{N|D_{k}|}{\sum_{i}|D_{i}|}\sum_{d\in D_{k}}\frac{l(w,d)}{|D_{k}|} is the scaled local objective function associated with client k𝑘k.

Once the global model weights are received by client k𝑘k, it tries compute the local gradient based on the function Fk​(w)subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤F_{k}(w). This local gradient is often computed using a random mini-batch of the local dataset and hence is associated with a noise corresponding to the random sampling. Let the local gradient be represented by ∇F~k​(w)∇subscript~𝐹𝑘𝑤\nabla\tilde{F}_{k}(w). These local stochastic gradients (SGD gradients) are then sent back to the PS where they are aggregated. Let Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} be the set of clients that successfully sent back their updates (local gradients) in round t𝑡t before the deadline T𝑇T. Then, the global model at the PS will be updated as follows,

(2) wt+1=wt−ηt​𝟙{|St|≥M}|St|​∑k∈St∇F~k​(wt),subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript1subscript𝑆𝑡𝑀subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑘subscript𝑆𝑡∇subscript~𝐹𝑘subscript𝑤𝑡\displaystyle w_{t+1}=w_{t}-\frac{\eta_{t}{\mathds{1}}_{\{|S_{t}|\geq M\}}}{|S_{t}|}\sum_{k\in S_{t}}\nabla\tilde{F}_{k}(w_{t}),

where ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} is the associated learning rate in round t𝑡t and 𝟙{⋅}subscript1⋅{\mathds{1}}_{\{\cdot\}} is the indicator function. We term the FL scheme described above as the M𝑀M-client update (MCU) scheme.

4. Cost and Age Metrics

In this section, we describe the metrics of interest for the FL model described in Section 3.

4.1. Resource Wastage

We define the resource wastage Cwsubscript𝐶𝑤C_{w} as the total time spent on processing updates that were eventually discarded at the PS. Let n𝑛n represent the number of clients that responded back by T𝑇T in a particular training round. In each training round, if n<M𝑛𝑀n<M we assume the round has failed and therefore all the received updates would be discarded. If n≥M𝑛𝑀n\geq M, then the PS would use all updates it received during that particular training round, resulting in a wastage of resources only in the clients that failed to send their local gradients by time T𝑇T. Under this scheme, the resource wastage in each round is as follows,

4.2. Communication Cost

Another metric of importance is the communication cost incurred per successful update of the global model. This is denoted by Cbsubscript𝐶𝑏C_{b} and is defined to be equal to the number of communication rounds required for a successful training round. Then, the average communication cost 𝔼​[Cb]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑏{\mathbb{E}}[C_{b}] isgiven by,

(6) 𝔼​[Cb]=𝔼​[K]=11−q,𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑏𝔼delimited-[]𝐾11𝑞\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}[C_{b}]={\mathbb{E}}[K]=\frac{1}{1-q},

where K𝐾K and q𝑞q are as defined in the proof of Theorem 1. Following similar arguments as in the proof of Theorem 1, for a fixed T𝑇T, choosing M=1𝑀1M=1 minimizes the average communication cost.

4.3. Average of Age of the Client

The average age of the client is the time average of the associated AoI process corresponding to the client updates. In particular, the age of a client k𝑘k denoted by ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k}, increases linearly until the client under consideration participates in a successful round and provides its local gradient to the PS. Once a successful update from the client is received, then ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} will drop to T𝑇T. This is based on the assumption that we update the global model only at the end of the training round while the local training is assumed to start at the beginning of a training round. In particular, for every failed training round, the round duration would be T𝑇T and for a successful training round, even if all N𝑁N clients managed to send updates before time T𝑇T, we would update the global model only after T𝑇T has elapsed (for N≫2​Mmuch-greater-than𝑁2𝑀N\gg 2M probability that all clients finish before T𝑇T is very small and therefore round duration would be T𝑇T almost surely). Hence, the age drops to T𝑇T once an update has been successfully received. Figure 2 shows how the age of the k𝑘kth client evolves under the above assumptions.

Since we consider N𝑁N homogeneous clients (i.e., the same update rate λ𝜆\lambda), we only need to consider the age of one particular client. Under the above assumptions, Theorem 3 gives the average age of a client at the PS.

Theorem 3.

For a finite T𝑇T, the time averaged age of the client at the PS is given by,

Corollary 0.

For a fixed T𝑇T, the optimal M𝑀M that minimizes the average age of the client is M=1𝑀1M=1.

Proof:  To minimize 𝔼​[Δk]𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΔ𝑘{\mathbb{E}}[\Delta_{k}], we need to maximize the term p​P​r​(n~≥M−1)𝑝𝑃𝑟~𝑛𝑀1pPr(\tilde{n}\geq M-1), which is achieved by setting M=1𝑀1M=1.  ■■\blacksquare

Remark 1.

Though at a first thought, the average age of the client may seem a relatively unrelated metric for FL, in the next section, we will show through a rigorous convergence analysis that 𝔼​[Δk]𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΔ𝑘{\mathbb{E}}[\Delta_{k}] is directly associated with the rate of convergence of the model for the considered FL scheme.

Remark 2.

When we set M=1𝑀1M=1, this corresponds to the situation where the PS uses the local gradients of all the clients it has received by time T𝑇T, to update the global model. In this case, if only a few clients responded, then the net gradient vector used to update the global model would be noisy.

5. Convergence Analysis

In this section, we provide the convergence analysis of the MCU scheme described in Section 3. We closely follow the outline of the convergence analysis in (Li et al., 2020b) and use the following assumptions to proceed in our analysis.

Assumption 1.

The loss functions at all clients are L𝐿L-smooth. For any x,y𝑥𝑦x,y, the loss function at client k𝑘k satisfies,

(9) Fk​(y)≤Fk​(x)+(y−x)T​∇Fk​(x)+L2​‖y−x‖2.subscript𝐹𝑘𝑦subscript𝐹𝑘𝑥superscript𝑦𝑥𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑥𝐿2superscriptnorm𝑦𝑥2\displaystyle F_{k}(y)\leq F_{k}(x)+(y-x)^{T}\nabla F_{k}(x)+\frac{L}{2}\|y-x\|^{2}.
Assumption 2.

The loss functions at all clients are μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex. For any x,y𝑥𝑦x,y, the loss function at client k𝑘k satisfies,

(10) Fk​(y)≥Fk​(x)+(y−x)T​∇Fk​(x)+μ2​‖y−x‖2.subscript𝐹𝑘𝑦subscript𝐹𝑘𝑥superscript𝑦𝑥𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑥𝜇2superscriptnorm𝑦𝑥2\displaystyle F_{k}(y)\geq F_{k}(x)+(y-x)^{T}\nabla F_{k}(x)+\frac{\mu}{2}\|y-x\|^{2}.
Assumption 3.

The SGD gradient at each client is an unbiased estimator of its actual gradient with respect to the client dataset and has bounded variance,

(11) 𝔼​[∇F~k​(x)|x]𝔼delimited-[]conditional∇subscript~𝐹𝑘𝑥𝑥\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla\tilde{F}_{k}(x)|x] =∇Fk​(x),absent∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑥\displaystyle=\nabla F_{k}(x),
(12) 𝔼​[‖∇Fk​(x)−∇F~k​(x)‖]𝔼delimited-[]norm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑥∇subscript~𝐹𝑘𝑥\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}[\|\nabla F_{k}(x)-\nabla\tilde{F}_{k}(x)\|] ≤σ2,absentsuperscript𝜎2\displaystyle\leq\sigma^{2},

where ∇Fk​(x)∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑥\nabla F_{k}(x) is the actual gradient at the k𝑘kth client.

Assumption 4.

The SGD gradients between clients are independent. For all k,l∈{1,2,…,N}𝑘𝑙12…𝑁k,l\in\{1,2,\dots,N\}, and model x𝑥x, (∇Fk​(x)−∇F~k​(x))⟂(∇Fl​(x)−∇F~l​(x))perpendicular-to∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑥∇subscript~𝐹𝑘𝑥∇subscript𝐹𝑙𝑥∇subscript~𝐹𝑙𝑥(\nabla F_{k}(x)-\nabla\tilde{F}_{k}(x))\perp(\nabla F_{l}(x)-\nabla\tilde{F}_{l}(x)).

Definition 0.

The heterogeneity of the data distribution across the clients is given by Γ=F∗−1N​∑k=1NFk∗Γsuperscript𝐹1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘\Gamma=F^{*}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=1}^{N}F_{k}^{*}, where F∗superscript𝐹F^{*} is the global optimum and Fk∗subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑘F^{*}_{k} is the local optimum with respect to Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}.

Remark 3.

Since the terms N​|Dk|∑i|Di|𝑁subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖\frac{N|D_{k}|}{\sum_{i}|D_{i}|} have been absorbed into the loss function Fk​(w)subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤F_{k}(w), σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} in Assumption 3 is proportional to m​a​xk​N​|Dk|∑i|Di|𝑚𝑎subscript𝑥𝑘𝑁subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖max_{k}\frac{N|D_{k}|}{\sum_{i}|D_{i}|}. Therefore, if we have have a highly non uniform distribution of samples among clients, σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} would also increase.

Under the above assumptions, Theorem 2 below gives a bound on the expected deviation from the global optimum after t𝑡t training rounds for the MCU scheme.

Theorem 2.

Under the MCU scheme, the expected optimality gap after t𝑡t iterations satisfies the following bound,

(13) 𝔼​[F​(wt)]−F∗≤L(2​L+S~​N​μ​t)​((4​L​Γ+2​σ2M)μ+(L+N​μ​S~)​ε1),𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡superscript𝐹𝐿2𝐿~𝑆𝑁𝜇𝑡4𝐿Γ2superscript𝜎2𝑀𝜇𝐿𝑁𝜇~𝑆subscript𝜀1\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}[F(w_{t})]-F^{*}\leq\frac{L}{(2L+\tilde{S}N\mu t)}\left(\frac{(4L\Gamma+\frac{2\sigma^{2}}{M})}{\mu}+(L+N\mu\tilde{S})\varepsilon_{1}\right),

The proof of Theorem 2 is given in Appendix A. We have the following corollary.

Corollary 0.

Under the MCU scheme, the convergence bound is O​(1t​p​P​r​(n~≥M−1))𝑂1𝑡𝑝𝑃𝑟~𝑛𝑀1O\left(\frac{1}{tpPr(\tilde{n}\geq M-1)}\right), where n~∼B​i​n​o​r​m​(N−1,p)similar-to~𝑛𝐵𝑖𝑛𝑜𝑟𝑚𝑁1𝑝\tilde{n}\sim Binorm(N-1,p). Proof:  For large t𝑡t the inequality (13) reduces to the following,

Moreover, S~~𝑆\tilde{S} can be bounded as follows,

6. Optimal design parameters

For the MCU scheme, we consider, the least number of learners required M𝑀M, and the reporting deadline T𝑇T as controllable design parameters of our model. According to Corollary 2 and (6), we notice that setting M=1𝑀1M=1 minimizes both the resource wastage and the communication cost. When the data distribution across clients is non i.i.d. and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is small, Corollary 3 shows that the optimality gap is bounded by 𝔼​[Δk]T𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΔ𝑘𝑇\frac{{\mathbb{E}}[\Delta_{k}]}{T}. Therefore, we can use 𝔼​[Δk]T𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΔ𝑘𝑇\frac{{\mathbb{E}}[\Delta_{k}]}{T} as a metric to quantify the accuracy of the model. This would imply that having a large T𝑇T would be beneficial for the model to converge faster (i.e., the number of training rounds required is lower). However, this does not take into account the duration of the training rounds. Therefore, we choose to use 𝔼​[Δk]𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΔ𝑘{\mathbb{E}}[\Delta_{k}] as a metric which encapsulates both the model accuracy and the round duration into account. According to Corollary 4, setting M=1𝑀1M=1 minimizes the age, and therefore leads to faster convergence. Thus, we choose M=1𝑀1M=1 as the optimal design parameter in this setting. Therefore, what remains is to find the optimal report deadline T𝑇T, that minimizes the computational cost wastage, communication cost and age of clients.

Remark 4.

When the variance of the stochastic gradient σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is high (compared to 4​L​Γ4𝐿Γ4L\Gamma and L​μ​ε1𝐿𝜇subscript𝜀1L\mu\varepsilon_{1}) , setting M=1𝑀1M=1 would not necessarily mean faster convergence. In particular, then the convergence rate is inversely proportional to the product M​P​r​(n~≥M−1).𝑀𝑃𝑟~𝑛𝑀1MPr(\tilde{n}\geq M-1).

Next, we scalarize our multi-objective optimization problem as follows. Let αwsubscript𝛼𝑤\alpha_{w} and αbsubscript𝛼𝑏\alpha_{b} denote the relative weights associated with 𝔼​[Cw]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑤{\mathbb{E}}[C_{w}] and 𝔼​[Cb]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑏{\mathbb{E}}[C_{b}] with respect to 𝔼​[Δk]𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΔ𝑘{\mathbb{E}}[\Delta_{k}]. Then, the goal is to minimize the following objective function J​(λ,T)𝐽𝜆𝑇J(\lambda,T),

J​(λ,T)=𝐽𝜆𝑇absent\displaystyle J(\lambda,T)= αw​𝔼​[Cw]+αb​𝔼​[Cb]+𝔼​[Δk]subscript𝛼𝑤𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑤subscript𝛼𝑏𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑏𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΔ𝑘\displaystyle\alpha_{w}{\mathbb{E}}[C_{w}]+\alpha_{b}{\mathbb{E}}[C_{b}]+{\mathbb{E}}[\Delta_{k}]
(17) =\displaystyle= αw​N​T​e−λ​T1−e−N​λ​T+αb1−e−N​λ​T+λ​Tλ​(12+11−e−λ​T).subscript𝛼𝑤𝑁𝑇superscript𝑒𝜆𝑇1superscript𝑒𝑁𝜆𝑇subscript𝛼𝑏1superscript𝑒𝑁𝜆𝑇𝜆𝑇𝜆1211superscript𝑒𝜆𝑇\displaystyle\alpha_{w}\frac{NTe^{-\lambda T}}{1-e^{-N\lambda T}}+\frac{\alpha_{b}}{1-e^{-N\lambda T}}+\frac{\lambda T}{\lambda}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{1-e^{-\lambda T}}\right).

Taking x=λ​T𝑥𝜆𝑇x=\lambda T in (17) yields the following optimization problem,

minxsubscript𝑥\displaystyle\min_{x} J​(x)𝐽𝑥\displaystyle\quad J(x)
(18) s.t. x≥0,𝑥0\displaystyle\quad x\geq 0,

where J​(x)=αw​N​x​e−xλ​(1−e−N​x)+αb1−e−N​x+xλ​(12+11−e−x)𝐽𝑥subscript𝛼𝑤𝑁𝑥superscript𝑒𝑥𝜆1superscript𝑒𝑁𝑥subscript𝛼𝑏1superscript𝑒𝑁𝑥𝑥𝜆1211superscript𝑒𝑥J(x)=\alpha_{w}\frac{Nxe^{-x}}{\lambda(1-e^{-Nx})}+\frac{\alpha_{b}}{1-e^{-Nx}}+\frac{x}{\lambda}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{1-e^{-x}}\right). Unfortunately, (18) is not a convex optimization problem. However, the second and third term are convex functions and the first term is a bounded function for x≥0𝑥0x\geq 0. Therefore, for small values of αwsubscript𝛼𝑤\alpha_{w}, this can be approximated as a convex optimization problem. Moreover, as x→0→𝑥0x\to 0 the second term goes to ∞\infty and as x→∞→𝑥x\to\infty the third term goes to ∞\infty. Therefore, even for large values of αwsubscript𝛼𝑤\alpha_{w}, we can simply do an exhaustive search within a reasonable bounded space to find the optimal point. Figure 3 depicts the typical variation of J​(x)𝐽𝑥J(x) with x𝑥x.

7. Heterogeneous Client Schemes

In the MCU scheme, setting M=1𝑀1M=1 in general minimizes the resource wastage while having a faster convergence rate. However, this is under the assumption that the clients are homogeneous. If the clients are heterogeneous with respect to their processing power, setting M=1𝑀1M=1 would not be ideal. This is mainly due to the fact that the PS would be dominated by faster clients. This would be especially degrading in cases where the faster clients have bad datasets or in the event that the faster clients are adversarial in nature. Therefore, setting M>1𝑀1M>1 would be beneficial in these cases. However, if we adhere to the MCU scheme, this would come at the cost of increased resource wastage and communication costs. Therefore, we propose two schemes that would help mitigate the issues that would arise with heterogeneous clients.

7.1. Age Weighted Update (AWU)

When a certain client has not updated the model for several rounds, the global model tends to drift away from the optimal with respect to the dataset of that particular client. In that case, giving more weight to client that has not updated the model in a long time would seem beneficial. Moreover, if a certain client always updates our model compared to others, the global model tends to get biased towards the local dataset of that particular client, which can also be detrimental to the system if the client dataset is not good or if the client is an adversary. Therefore, in this setting we update the model by weighting the client gradients based on a bounded increasing function of the age of the client at the PS. Moreover, we set M=1𝑀1M=1 so as to allow the global model to be updated in each round and increase the resource efficiency. In this scheme, the global model is updated as follows,

(19) wt+1=wt−ηt​𝟙{|St|≥1}∑j∈StQ​(Δj)​∑k∈StQ​(Δk)​∇F~k​(wt),subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript1subscript𝑆𝑡1subscript𝑗subscript𝑆𝑡𝑄subscriptΔ𝑗subscript𝑘subscript𝑆𝑡𝑄subscriptΔ𝑘∇subscript~𝐹𝑘subscript𝑤𝑡\displaystyle w_{t+1}=w_{t}-\frac{\eta_{t}{\mathds{1}}_{\{|S_{t}|\geq 1\}}}{\sum_{j\in S_{t}}Q(\Delta_{j})}\sum_{k\in S_{t}}Q(\Delta_{k})\nabla\tilde{F}_{k}(w_{t}),

where ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} is the age of the k𝑘kth client at the PS and Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot) is a positive bounded increasing function.

7.2. Aggregated Gradient Update (AGU)

In the presence of heterogeneous clients, operating with M>1𝑀1M>1 in the MCU scheme can help the PS from being overwhelmed by faster clients. However, this would increase the number of failed rounds, and discarding the gradients that have been computed in the failed rounds would be a waste of resources. Therefore, in this scheme, we aggregate the computed gradients across failed rounds and update the global model based on the aggregated gradients received when a round is successful. In this scheme, the global model is updated as follows,

(20) wt+1=wt−ηt​𝟙{|St|≥M}|St|​∑k∈St∇F¯k​(wt),subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript1subscript𝑆𝑡𝑀subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑘subscript𝑆𝑡∇subscript¯𝐹𝑘subscript𝑤𝑡\displaystyle w_{t+1}=w_{t}-\frac{\eta_{t}{\mathds{1}}_{\{|S_{t}|\geq M\}}}{|S_{t}|}\sum_{k\in S_{t}}\nabla\bar{F}_{k}(w_{t}),

where ∇F¯k​(wt)∇subscript¯𝐹𝑘subscript𝑤𝑡\nabla\bar{F}_{k}(w_{t}) is the accumulated stochastic gradient of the k𝑘kth client across the failed rounds until a successful round occurs. When a round is successful, the gradients are re-accumulated across failed rounds for the new global model. In other words, on the event of a failed round, the successful client would not restart the local training from the current global model but rather would continue its local training starting from its new local model. When a round is successful, all the local models will be re-synchronized with the global model.

8. Numerical Results

In this section, we validate our theoretical results through several experiments.

Experimental settings. For simulations, we use MNIST dataset which consists of 10 classes, each corresponding to a different handwritten digit (Den, 2012). Out of the total 60000 data points in the MNIST dataset, 50000 are used for the training set and 10000 is used for the test set. In each of the experiments, we consider 100 clients (N=100𝑁100N=100) where each client is allocated a local dataset by sampling the training set of the MNIST dataset appropriately. For each experiment, we use a simpler 4 layer perceptron model. To evaluate the model performance, in each of the experiments, we train the global model at least 1000 training rounds to achieve stable results and evaluate its accuracy on the test set of the MNIST dataset. The learning rate of each client is set at λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1 in all experiments. To simulate the local training time of clients, at the beginning of each training round, we obtain a random sample from E​x​p​(λ)𝐸𝑥𝑝𝜆Exp(\lambda) distribution for each client. If there are at least M𝑀M clients whose associated random sample is less than T𝑇T, then we allow those clients to update the global model. Otherwise, the round is assumed to be failed and a new training round is started from the beginning.

8.1. I.I.D. vs Non I.I.D. Data Distribution

In the first numerical experiment, we compare how the accuracy varies with M𝑀M for a given value of T𝑇T when the data distribution among clients is non i.i.d. in nature. For each client, we assign 3 classes by allocating a unique combination of classes from among (N3)binomial𝑁3N\choose 3 ways of selecting 3 classes out of 10. Further, each client is allocated an equal number of data points so as to achieve a small σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} value. Figure 4 shows that by selecting M=1𝑀1M=1 in general yields a higher accuracy compared to larger values of M𝑀M. This increase in accuracy becomes more prominent as T𝑇T increases. This is to be expected since we have intentionally distributed data so as to increase the ΓΓ\Gamma while maintaining a small value for σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. From (16) it is evident that the optimality gap will be inversely proportional to P​r​(n~≥M−1)𝑃𝑟~𝑛𝑀1Pr(\tilde{n}\geq M-1). Hence, setting M=1𝑀1M=1 would lead to higher accuracy.

Next, we repeat the same experiment as above, when the client datasets are sampled in an i.i.d. manner. In this experiment, each client is allocated an equal number of randomly sampled data points from each of the 10 classes. We note that for some experiments in this case, setting M=1𝑀1M=1 would not be optimal for comparatively larger values of T𝑇T. Figure 5 shows one such scenario. As seen in Figure 5, when M𝑀M increases from M=1𝑀1M=1 to M=30𝑀30M=30, the accuracy has increased but as M𝑀M increases further the accuracy has decreased. This behavior is similar in nature to the behavior predicted in Remark 4. If the initial deviation ε1subscript𝜀1\varepsilon_{1} and ΓΓ\Gamma is comparatively small, then the model performance will be proportional to M​P​r​(n~≥M−1)𝑀𝑃𝑟~𝑛𝑀1MPr(\tilde{n}\geq M-1). Figure 6 shows M​P​r​(n~≥M−1)𝑀𝑃𝑟~𝑛𝑀1MPr(\tilde{n}\geq M-1) will achieve its maximum around M=33𝑀33M=33 and will decrease rapidly as it comes closer to M=40𝑀40M=40. Therefore, we believe that in this experiment the ideal conditions were met to achieve the predicted behavior. However, this behavior may not be observable for all i.i.d. distributions as it depends on ε1subscript𝜀1\varepsilon_{1} as well.

Moreover, even if we distribute the classes to the clients in a non i.i.d. manner, if the number of data points allocated for each client is significantly different, then again we start to observe the above behavior for larger T𝑇T values. This is due to the fact that σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is directly related to how the data points are distributed among the clients as suggested by Remark 3. In general, the graph of M​P​r​(n~≥M−1)𝑀𝑃𝑟~𝑛𝑀1MPr(\tilde{n}\geq M-1) can be used as a good indicator to determine whether M>1𝑀1M>1 would significantly degrade the model accuracy for a given T𝑇T. However, it is not a guaranteed indicator of which M𝑀M value would yield the maximum accuracy due to various assumptions used in the proofs (see Figure 7). Additionally, even in cases where M>1𝑀1M>1 yields a higher accuracy, the improvement over the case when M=1𝑀1M=1 is very small. Therefore, M=1𝑀1M=1 is good choice for the minimum numbers of learners required per round.

8.2. Resource Efficiency vs Accuracy

As seen from the previous section, even though there may be instances where the model accuracy achieves its peak for a larger M𝑀M, the difference is very insignificant compared to the instance M=1𝑀1M=1 (see Figure 5). Therefore, as suggested in Section 6, we set M=1𝑀1M=1 and explore how the resource wastage, communication cost, normalized age 𝔼​[Δk]/T𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΔ𝑘𝑇{{\mathbb{E}}[\Delta_{k}]}/{T} are linked to the parameter T𝑇T. In this experiment, each client is allocated a single class (client k𝑘k is allocated class k𝑘k mod 10 ) and an arbitrary number data points are sampled.

Figure 8 shows the variation of the quantities of interest with T𝑇T. We see that the communication cost remains almost at 1 in each of the experiments as shown in Figure 8(b). This is due to the fact that we are using a large number of clients. Therefore, almost every training round is a successful round for the considered T𝑇T values. We observe that the model accuracy increases with T𝑇T (see Figure 8(d)) while the normalized age decreases with T𝑇T (see Figure 8(c)). This validates the result given by Corollary 3. We also note that as T𝑇T increases, the resource wastage, first increases and then starts to decrease (see Figure 8(a)). This is because, as T𝑇T increases, more time is wasted by failed clients, resulting in an increase in resource wastage. But as T𝑇T increases further, the number of clients that fail also decreases, resulting in a decrease in resource wastage. In general, as seen by Figure 8, it may seem that by increasing T𝑇T, we would be able to achieve a higher accuracy and resource efficiency. However, this is not ideal as it does not consider the fact that larger T𝑇T would imply longer round duration. In fact, a similar accuracy and resource efficiency can be achieved at T=0.5𝑇0.5T=0.5 when compared to T=2𝑇2T=2, but with 1414\frac{1}{4}th the time spent on training. Therefore, T=0.5𝑇0.5T=0.5, might be a better solution in this particular scenario.

8.3. Heterogeneous Client Schemes

Age Weighted Update (AWU). Now we compare the performance of the AWU scheme with the MCU scheme. In this experiment, we consider a certain percentage of clients to be extremely biased clients (i.e., local datasets are biased towards a certain class or few data points). For a biased client, we sample a few data points from class 0 and replicate them in their local datasets to match the number of data points of unbiased clients. For unbiased clients, we uniformly assign a single class from classes 1 to 9 (client k𝑘k is assigned class {k​mod​ 9}+1𝑘mod91\{k\;\text{mod}\;9\}+1 ) and randomly sample a certain number of data points from the allocated class. In this experiment, we choose Q​(x)=(min⁡{x,10})2𝑄𝑥superscript𝑥102Q(x)=(\min\{x,10\})^{2} as the age based weighting function. In here, we further assume that, these biased clients are faster and provide updates in every training round. The variation of accuracy with the percentage of biased clients, for MCU and AWU schemes, is shown in Table 1. As depicted in Table 1, when the number of biased clients is fairly low, MCU with M=1𝑀1M=1 seems to perform comparatively better than the AWU scheme. But as the number of biased clients increases, the AWU scheme seems to maintain its accuracy, while MCU scheme exhibits a significant reduction in accuracy.

Aggregated Gradient Update (AGU). Next, we evaluate the performance of the MCU scheme against the AGU scheme when M>1𝑀1M>1. In this experiment, the client datasets are created by choosing a random number of classes to be allocated for each client and from each allocated class a random number of data points are sampled. For the AGU scheme, we use a fixed learning rate as opposed to the decaying learning rate used in MCU. Empirical evidence shows that a decaying learning rate works better for MCU scheme while a fixed learning rate is better for AGU scheme. The variation of the model accuracy with M𝑀M, for the two schemes, is shown in Table 2. As shown in Table 2, as M𝑀M increases the performance degradation of MCU becomes more apparent when compared to the AGU scheme. For smaller M𝑀M values, their performances look identical with MCU having a slight edge over AGU.

9. Conclusion

In this work, we have uncovered how age is fundamentally associated with the model accuracy for the studied MCU scheme and have provided analytical methods to fine tune the system parameters to achieve the desired balance between resource efficiency and model performance. We have shown that, in general, updating with the available number of clients without waiting for a large number of clients can yield better model performance in terms of both model accuracy and convergence time. We have also introduced two schemes that can be used in the presence heterogeneous clients and have shown through numerical results, that these two schemes are more reliable in the presence of biased or adversarial clients.

It is shown in (Li et al., 2020b) that, if the deviation of the model from the optimal point in round (t+1)𝑡1(t+1) is upper bounded by the deviation of the model from the optimal point in round t𝑡t for some constants A𝐴A and B𝐵B as given in (A), then by choosing ηt=βγ+tsubscript𝜂𝑡𝛽𝛾𝑡\eta_{t}=\frac{\beta}{\gamma+t} such that β>1A𝛽1𝐴\beta>\frac{1}{A}, γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 and satisfies η1≤min⁡{1A,1L}subscript𝜂11𝐴1𝐿\eta_{1}\leq\min\{\frac{1}{A},\frac{1}{L}\}, we can bound the optimality gap of round t𝑡t as follows,
